etymologies: Middle English (denoting a flat, thin sheet, usually of metal): from Old French, from medieval Latin plata ‘plate armor’, based on Greek platus ‘flat’. plate (sense 1 of the noun) represents Old French plat ‘platter, large dish’, also ‘dish of meat’, noun use of Old French plat ‘flat’

definitions: a flat dish, typically circular and made of china, from which food is eaten or served

examples.text: he pushed his empty plate to one side and sipped his wine
a dinner plate

definitions: an amount of food on a plate

examples.text: a plate of spaghetti

definitions: a course of a meal, served on one plate

examples.text: I'll have the salad plate

definitions: a flat dish, typically made of metal or wood, passed around a church congregation in order to collect donations of money

examples.text: they brought around the collection plates

definitions: a shallow glass dish on which a culture of cells or microorganisms may be grown

examples.text: a tissue culture plate

shortDefinitions: glass dish on which cells may be grown

definitions: dishes, bowls, cups, and other utensils made of gold, silver, or other metal
etymologies: from Old French vaisselle en plate ‘dishes and plates made of a single piece of metal’

examples.text: an exhibition of the plate belonging to the college

shortDefinitions: dishes made of gold or silver

definitions: a silver or gold dish or trophy awarded as a prize in a race or competition

examples.text: she lifted the plate in victory

shortDefinitions: dish or trophy awarded as prize

definitions: a race or competition in which a silver or gold trophy is awarded

examples.text: the final of the Ladies' Plate at Henley

shortDefinitions: race in which such prize is awarded

definitions: a thin, flat sheet or strip of metal or other material, typically one used to join or strengthen things or forming part of a machine

examples.text: he underwent surgery to have a steel plate put into his leg

shortDefinitions: flat sheet of metal used to strengthen or join

definitions: a small, flat piece of metal or other material bearing a name or inscription and attached to a door or other object

examples.text: a brass plate with her initials
the car had Vermont plates

definitions: a piece of lumber laid horizontally along the top of a wall to support the ends of joists or rafters.
shortDefinitions: horizontal timber supporting ends of joists etc.

definitions: a light horseshoe for a racehorse.
a thin, flat organic structure or formation

examples.text: the fused bony plates protect the tortoise's soft parts

definitions: each of the several rigid pieces of the earth's lithosphere which together make up the earth's surface.

examples.text: the Pacific Ocean plate

definitions: a sheet of metal, plastic, or some other material bearing an image of type or illustrations from which multiple copies are printed

examples.text: the correct alignment of the plates in four-color printing

shortDefinitions: sheet of metal etc. from which to print

definitions: a printed photograph, picture, or illustration, especially one on superior-quality paper in a book

examples.text: the book contains sixty color plates

definitions: a thin sheet of metal, glass, or other substance coated with a light-sensitive film on which an image is formed, used in larger or older types of cameras.
shortDefinitions: sheet of metal etc. coated with light-sensitive film

definitions: a thin piece of plastic molded to the shape of a person's mouth and gums, to which artificial teeth or another orthodontic appliance are attached.
shortDefinitions: piece of plastic to which orthodontic appliances are attached

definitions: a complete denture or orthodontic appliance.
a thin piece of metal that acts as an electrode in a capacitor, battery, or cell.
the anode of a thermionic tube.
cover (a metal object) with a thin coating or film of a different metal

examples.text: she had already taken the coin to a jeweler to be plated
the cylinder is nickel-plated

shortDefinitions: cover metal with coating of different metal

definitions: cover (an object) with plates of metal for decoration, protection, or strength

examples.text: the ship is plated in the bows with steel eighteen millimeters thick

definitions: serve or arrange (food) on a plate or plates before a meal

examples.text: overcooked vegetables won't look appetizing, no matter how they are plated

definitions: score (a run or runs); cause (someone) to score

examples.text: Matt Wignot plated two of Clarkson's runs

definitions: inoculate (cells or infective material) on to a culture plate, especially with the object of isolating a particular strain of microorganisms or estimating viable cell numbers.
